Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Assessing Vulnerabilities from Climate Change: Impacts of Water Provision, Power Relations and Perceptions of Risk on Ecohydrology in the Tampa Bay Region Socioecosystem

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Thr research supported by this award will build on activities supported by NSF Urban Long-Term Research Area (ULTRA-Ex) Award 0948986, which investigates how social organization and distribution of power in a socioecosystem-driven resource redistribution of a key resource, water, in the Tampa Bay metropolitan region. In previous work, the investigators have identified relationships among wetland ecohydrological conditions, water redistribution, social power, and perceptions of ecological change in the Tampa Bay regional socioecosystem. Through this award, they will develop and examine new scenarios regarding how this complex socioecological network might be modified by climate change. The investigators will focus their efforts on three core questions: (1) How have social organizations and distribution of power shaped current planning, perceptions of risk, and adaptation to climate change in the water provision system in Tampa Bay? (2) How do key stakeholders, decision makers, and residents perceive climate change vulnerabilities related to water quality and quantity in the Tampa Bay regional socioecosystem? (3) How will natural systems respond to regional socioecosystem-specific climate change scenarios that will impact water quality and quantity? They will collect and analyze quantitative and qualitative data on perceptions of risk and adaptive capacity of the region's water system to climate change through interviews with key stakeholders, and they will statistically downscale currently available Florida climate scenarios for the region. They will develop three climate change scenarios of varying impact (low, moderate, and high), building on existing scenarios, drawing on interview responses, and testing these scenarios by using surveys with a second sample of key stakeholders and residents to assess perceptions, acceptability, and adaptive capacities. They also will measure and analyze ecological indicators in order to model the biophysical behavior of the water systems under the varying climate change scenarios.

The project will develop ethnographically informed scenarios of climate change impacts on water quality and quantity that will reveal power differentials, conflicting values, and institutional barriers that shape adaptive capacity, contributing to socioecological and political ecology theory. Research results will have fundamental research value and will be disseminated broadly through presentations at public meetings, easily accessible summary reports, and through formal interactions with project partners, such as Tampa Bay Water, the primary regional water-supply wholesaler, and the Southwest Florida Water Management District, the water-supply regulatory authority. Communication with research teams conducting similar projects at other ULTRA-Ex sites will facilitate development of more impactful measures and indicators of urban vulnerability to climate change. This project is supported with funds transferred to the National Science Foundation by the Environmental Protection Agency.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our interdisciplinary project is interested in understanding public perceptions of climate change risk and vulnerability in the Tampa Bay region, specifically focused on how climate change is likely to impact water infrastructure in the area. As part of the project, our research team developed localized climate change scenarios based on global climate models, Florida-centric models, and input from key informants. We were interested in how these localized scenarios can be designed to incorporate multiple viewpoints from climate scientists, policy makers, and planning and environmental organizations to effectively communicate to the public through engaging narrative and visual formats.

Developing local scenarios of climate change impacts on water quality and quantity has revealed what issues and which places people living in the Tampa Bay region consider important and of significant concern. We developed ways to document which places on the landscape residents are most concerned about being damaged by sea level rise. We asked participants in public workshops to think beyond sea level rise to consider how climate change will affect many aspects of their daily lives in the future, such as transportation, agriculture, water, and non-human species.

We also asked these questions: How do climate scientists communicate with the public? What do residents understand about the risks to their local environments and communities from sea level rise, increased flooding during rainy season, or changes in predictability and seasonality of rainfall?

Our aim was to develop a way to consider how power and influence, conflicting values, and institutional barriers shape vulnerabilities to climate change in our region, contributing to socioecological and political ecology theory.

We suggest that responses of different audiences—concerned public, city councils, regional planners, environmental activists, climate scientists––to a set of localized climate scenarios could aid decision makers who confront multiple uncertainties with regards to how to plan for and adapt in the face of climate change. This has become especially important as the Tampa Bay region has been identified as being particularly vulnerable to climate change, as a large metropolitan area on the Florida coastline.

Climate-induced changes in water demand and water availability may affect the aquifer and how much groundwater is withdrawn in the future. Project members informed water resource managers and water policy makers about the ecohydrological consequences of changing aquifer water levels. Results have been shared with the water management community about wetland responses (e.g., plant composition, carbon and nitrogen storage) to changes in hydrology.

In general, the key informants we have interviewed suggest that sea level rise, changes in rainfall patterns, and flooding are likely to be the most significant impacts from climate change in the Tampa Bay region. The biggest risks to water infrastructure and ability to provide enough clean water to the area are saltwater intrusion from sea level rise, flooding of water stations (i.e. desalination plants) from sea level rise, and pollution of surface water from increased storm events. The participants think that in general most local residents in the Tampa Bay region are aware of the risks of climate change, but are either: 1) not sure what they can do about it on an individual level; or 2) are aware of sea level rise impacts but do not see the connection between global temperature rise and local temperature rise, and therefore do not think temperature rise is occurring locally. The process of creating localized climate scenarios is one that incorporates information from many different sources, creating a grounded way to visualize local impacts of climate change and consider possible solutions.
